Globals
Matreshka (MK)
MK.Object
MK.Array

Class: Array

Matreshka. Array

Matreshka Array class (Matreshka "collection"). Extends Matreshka.

new Array()

Author:
Andrey Gubanov
License:
MIT Version 2.0, January 2004
Source:
matreshka-array.js, line 124
Examples

Basic usage

new MK.Array;

Passing length

// creates Matreshka.Array instance with length = 42
new MK.Array( 42 );

Passing elements

// creates Matreshka.Array instance with length = 2
new MK.Array( 'Hi', { a: 'b' } );

Inheritance

var MyClass = Class({
	'extends': MK.Array,
	constructor: function() {
		// calls MK.Array constructor with same context and given arguments
		MyClass.parent.constructor( this, arguments );
	},
	method: function() {}
});

Methods

concat(array) → {mkArray}

Works similar to Array.prototype.concat

Returns: mkArray (new Matreshka.Array instance)
Arguments
array <repeatable>
 		Array Matreshka.Array (Array instance or MK.Array instance)
Source:
matreshka-array.js, line 635
Examples

Basic usage 1

var result = this.concat( [ 1, 2, 3 ] );

Basic usage 2

var mkArray = new MK.Array().createFrom( [ 1, 2, 3, 4, 5 ] ),
    result = this.concat( mkArray, [ 6, 7, 8 ] );

createFrom(array) → {mkArray}

Recreates Matreshka.Array instance from another array

You can convert array or array-like object (e.g. arguments) to Matreshka.Array instance using this method
Returns: mkArray (self)
Fires: recreate modify
Arguments
array Array
Source:
matreshka-array.js, line 275
Example

Basic usage

new MK.Array().createFrom( [1, 2, 3, 4, 5] );

Works similar to Matreshka.Array#forEach

Returns: mkArray (self)
Arguments
callback arrayCallback
thisArg <optional>
 		any
Source:
matreshka-array.js, line 979
Example

Basic usage

this.each( function( item, index ) {
	console.log( index, item ); 
});

Works similar to Array.prototype.every

Returns: boolean
Arguments
callback arrayCallback
thisArg <optional>
 		any
Source:
matreshka-array.js, line 914
Example

Basic usage

var isBigEnough = this.every( function( item ) {
	return item > 10;
});

var filtered = this.filter( function( item ) {
	 return item > 4;
});

Works similar to Array.prototype.forEach but returns self instead of undefined

Returns: mkArray (self)

thisArg <optional>
 		any

hasOwnProperty() → {boolean}

Tells is given property defined in the instance

Returns: boolean
Source:
matreshka-array.js, line 604
Example

Basic usage

var mkArray = new MK.Array( 42 ); // creates array with length = 42
mkArray.hasOwnProperty( 5 ); // true
mkArray.hasOwnProperty( 100500 ); // false
mkArray.hasOwnProperty( 'length' ); // true
mkArray.hasOwnProperty( 'blah' ); // false

indexOf(searchElement, fromIndex) → {string}

Works similar to Array.prototype.indexOf

Returns: string
Arguments
searchElement number
fromIndex <optional>
 		number
Source:
matreshka-array.js, line 1001
Example

Basic usage

var mkArray = new MK.Array().createFrom( [ 1, 2, 3, 4, 4, 3, 2, 1 ] );
alert( this.indexOf( 2 ) ); // alerts 1

initializeSmartArray() → {boolean}

Initializes "smart array"

This method is only needed when you're setting Matreshka.Array#itemRenderer property after some items are added.
Returns: boolean
Since:
0.1
Source:
matreshka-array.js, line 570
Examples

Basic usage

var mkArray = new MK.Array;
// DOM is not changing because itemRenderer is not assigned yet
mkArray.push( ... );
mkArray.itemRenderer = function() { '<div>MyDiv</div>' };
// DOM is changing after initializeSmartArray execution
mkArray.initializeSmartArray();

When initializeSmartArray is not needed

var mkArray = new MK.Array;
// setting itemRenderer before adding any item to array
mkArray.itemRenderer = function() { '<div>MyDiv</div>' };
// DOM is changing after push, no need to use initializeSmartArray
mkArray.push( ... );

initMK() → {mkArray}

Initializes Matreshka.Array instance. See Matreshka#initMK.

Returns: mkArray (self)
Source:
matreshka-array.js, line 364
Example

Basic usage

var MyClass = Class({
	'extends': MK.Array,
	constructor: function() {
 	this.initMK();
	}
});

itemRenderer() → {string|Node|jQuery}

Renderer for array items

This method equals to null by default. You can assign function that returns element for making {@Matreshka Array} to be "smart array" that changes DOM automatically when data is changed. Check live example to see how it works.
Returns: string Node jQuery (HTML or element)
Since:
0.1
Source:
matreshka-array.js, line 157
To Do:
  • Maybe clearer explanation

join(separator) → {string}

Works similar to Array.prototype.join

Returns: string
Arguments
separator string
Source:
matreshka-array.js, line 1025
Example

Basic usage

var mkArray = new MK.Array().createFrom( [ 1, 2, 3, 4, 4, 3, 2, 1 ] );
alert( this.join( ':' ) ); // alerts '1:2:3:4:4:3:2:1'

Works similar to Array.prototype.map

Arguments

 		any
Source:
matreshka-array.js, line 877
Example

Basic usage

var props = this.map( function( item ) {
	 return item.prop;
});

on()

Works same way as Matreshka#on and allows to attach event handlers for any existing and furite items

Since:
0.2
Source:
matreshka-array.js, line 217
Example
var mkArray = new MK.Array();
mkArray.on( '@something', function() {
	alert( 'something happens' )
});
mkArray.push( new MK );
mkArray[ 0 ].trigger( 'something' );

pop() → {*|undefined}

Works similar to Array.prototype.pop

Returns: any undefined (removed element)
Fires: pop remove modify
Source:
matreshka-array.js, line 724
Example

Basic usage

this.pop();

pull(index) → {*}

Removes Matreshka#Array element by given index and returns that element

Returns: any (Removed element)
Fires: pull modify
Arguments
index string number
Since:
0.1
Source:
matreshka-array.js, line 663
Example

Basic usage

var removed;
this.createFrom( [ 'a', 'b', 'c' ] );
removed = this.pull( 1 );
alert( removed ); // 'b'
alert( this.toString ); // 'a,c'

push(element) → {mkArray}

Works similar to Array.prototype.push but returns self instead of length

Returns: mkArray (self)
Fires: push add modify
Arguments
element <repeatable>
 		any
Source:
matreshka-array.js, line 711
Example

Basic usage

this.push( 1, 2, 3 );

reduce(callback, initialValue) → {*}

Works similar to Array.prototype.reduce

Returns: any
Arguments
callback function
initialValue <optional>
 		any
Source:
matreshka-array.js, line 940
Example

Basic usage

new MK.Array().createFrom( [0,1,2,3,4] ).reduce( function( previousValue, currentValue ) {
	return previousValue + currentValue;
});

Returns: any

initialValue <optional>
 		any

matreshka-array.js, line 953
Example

Basic usage

new MK.Array().createFrom( [0,1,2,3,4] ).reduceRight( function( previousValue, currentValue ) {
	return previousValue + currentValue;
});

Works similar to Array.prototype.reverse

this.reverse();

setItemMediator()

Transforms items values

This method is using when you want to keep your items to be a certain type (string, number, object...). Pay attention that new mediator overrides Model property
Since:
0.1
Source:
matreshka-array.js, line 195
Example
 
var mkArray = new MK.Array( 1, 2, 3, 4, 5 );
mkArray.setItemMediator( function( value ) {
	return String( value );
});
mkArray.push( 6, 7 );
mkArray.unshift( true, {} );

console.log( mkArray.toJSON() ); // [ "true", "[object Object]", "1", "2", "3", "4", "5", "6", "7" ]

shift() → {mkArray}

Works similar to Array.prototype.shift

Returns: mkArray (self)
Fires: shift remove modify
Source:
matreshka-array.js, line 749
Example

Basic usage

this.shift( 1, 2, 3 );

silentCreateFrom(array) → {mkArray}

Creates self from another array

Works similar to Matreshka.Array#createFrom but doesn't trigger events

silentPull(index) → {*}

Works similar to Matreshka.Array#pull but doesn't trigger events

Returns: any (Removed element)
Arguments
index string number
Since:
0.1
Source:
matreshka-array.js, line 690
Example

Basic usage

var removed;
this.createFrom( [ 'a', 'b', 'c' ] );
removed = this.silentPull( 1 );
alert( removed ); // 'b'
alert( this.toString ); // 'a,c'

Works similar to Matreshka.Array#sort but doesn't trigger events

Arguments

Source:

Examples

Basic usage

Sorting callback

this.silentSort( function( a, b ) {
	 return a > b ? -1 : 1;
});

toArray() → {Array}

Converts Matreshka.Array to Javascript Array

Returns: Array (Array instance)
Source:
matreshka-array.js, line 334
Example

Basic usage

this.toArray();

toJSON() → {object}

Converts Matreshka.Array instance to native array

The difference between Matreshka.Array#toJSON and Matreshka.Array#toArray is that Matreshka.Array#toJSON tries to call toJSON method for inner objects
Returns: object
Source:
matreshka-array.js, line 619
Example

Basic usage

var json = this.toJSON();

toNative() → {Array}

Does the same as Matreshka.Array#toArray

Returns: Array (Array instance)
Source:
matreshka-array.js, line 353
Example

Basic usage

this.toNative();

 		any

Members

isMKArray :boolean boolean

isMKArray is always true. It's using for easy Matreshka.Array instance detection.

Source:
matreshka-array.js, line 151
